Empires & Puzzles Tang Sanzang Review: The Very Fast Golden Cicada

Tang Sanzang brings Very Fast healing and cleansing to the table, but does this Journey hero have the stats to survive the modern meta? We analyze the 'Great Mystery of the River' to see if he's worth your rings.
Tang Sanzang Review: The Monk Who Heals Faster Than You Can Blink
Tang Sanzang: The Golden Cicada's Blink-of-an-Eye Healing

Tang Sanzang, also known by his fancy epithet "Great Mystery of the River," arrived in Empires & Puzzles in April 2024 as part of the Journey family (War of Three Kingdoms). He fits into the rare and coveted archetype of the

While his release was met with some controversy regarding changes from his Beta version (where he had a unique mana stack mechanic), the live version settled into a role similar to a "Very Fast, budget Hathor." He is a pure support hero designed to keep your team alive through sheer speed rather than massive raw numbers.

Tang Sanzang sports a classic, serene monk aesthetic. Adorned in traditional golden and red robes with a distinct headpiece, he wields a staff that looks like it could double as a heavy-duty walking stick for those long journeys to the West. He radiates a calm "I'm not mad, just disappointed in your puzzle skills" energy. The "Golden Cicada" skill icon is a nice nod to his lore, even if you won't actually see any insects flying around during the battle.
Let's be real—Tang Sanzang's stats are showing their age. Released in early 2024, his base power of
sits significantly below the modern benchmark of late 2025 heroes, who are pushing
His base health (~1750) is low compared to modern tanks who easily breach 2200.
His defense is respectable but requires heavy emblem and limit break investment to withstand hits from modern snipers.
As a healer, his attack stat is largely irrelevant, which is a mercy since it's also outdated.
by modern standards. If you plan to use him in high-level play, Limit Breaking (LB1 and preferably LB2) is mandatory to keep him from evaporating before he can cast his first heal.
This is his crown jewel. Charging in just 6.5 tiles (6 with a mana troop) means he can often fire
the enemy slash attacks or fast snipers.
While 500 HP isn't a massive number compared to slower healers (who push 800+), getting 500
this quickly is excellent for mitigating early board damage.
This is the skill's biggest caveat. He does
cleanse all ailments. He only removes the
cleansable ailment. If your team is buried under a pile of DoTs and defense downs, Tang will only peel off the top layer.
+20% defense is... cute. It's a small nudge, not a wall. However, it serves a secondary purpose: it triggers his passive and family bonuses.
In a standard raid, if he fires 3 times (which is easy at VF speed), that's 1500 effective HP added to your team.
The +20% defense buff is mathematically minor but can be the difference between a hero surviving a sniper shot with 50 HP or dying.
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities
The Journey family and his passives are where Tang Sanzang finds his true value engine.
The chance to extend buff duration is fantastic for his defense buff. If you run him with other Journey heroes (like
), that 2-turn defense buff could randomly become a 5-turn buff, making it much more reliable.

Every time Tang receives a buff (from himself or allies), he has a coin-flip chance to gain 10% Mana. This makes him incredibly "bouncy"—he fires, buffs himself, potentially gains mana, gets buffed by an ally, gains more mana, and is suddenly charged again.
Similar to the mana passive, this keeps his own survivability higher than his stats suggest.

is the perfect Aether Power for him. Since his stats are his weak point, a flat 20% reduction in incoming damage for the first 6 turns is exactly what he needs to survive the opening barrage and get his heal engine running.
Upon release, Tang was seen as a "balanced" alternative to the overpowered Construct and Goblin heroes. He was a solid chase hero for top players needing speed, but never quite "broke" the game like

The game has moved towards massive damage and massive stats. Tang's 500 heal feels smaller now when heroes have 3000+ HP. His cleanse limitation is also more painful in a meta dominated by heroes who inflict 3+ ailments at once.
. He is no longer a top-tier tank or defense hero. However, on

, particularly in Rush Wars or against heavy DoT teams where you need frequent small cleanses, he is still a valuable tool. He excels in "saving" a bad board by keeping your team alive just long enough to find tiles.
Tang Sanzang is a Monk, which is excellent for resisting ailments (combining with his cleanse).
Maximizes his survivability. His heal is fixed (500), so attack stats do not boost his healing. He needs every point of Defense and HP to survive modern snipers.
None, really. There is no reason to go Attack path.
path. He is a support hero; his job is to live.
Can change the tide of battle in just 6 tiles.
Converts early excess healing into a meat shield.
Gains mana and health when buffed, allowing for rapid-fire specials.
Innate resistance to ailments can stop him from being silenced or mana-blocked.
ailment. This can be disastrous against stackers or multi-debuffers.
Requires heavy investment (LB2) to not be a glass cannon (without the cannon part).
20% is negligible against modern defense-down ailments.
His passives and monk class make him very annoying for enemies to stop.
Excellent for sustaining a team against fast slash attacks.
Overheal is always king in PvE.
Tang's passive gives him mana when buffed. Pairing him with other heroes who spam buffs can make him fire repeatedly, keeping your team permanently overhealed.
Use Tang for immediate, emergency cleansing of the most dangerous recent ailment (like a Silence), and save Rigard for the full heavy cleanse when needed.
(creates a window where his def up is gone),
(mana control hurts him, though monk class helps).
Don't rely on him as your

If you pulled Tang Sanzang early, congrats! He will carry you through almost all map stages and low-tier raids. Prioritize leveling him as your main healer. His overheal effectively extends your team's max HP, making hard levels much easier.
He is a luxury tool. Do not prioritize him over modern meta supports like
or the latest Construct healers. However, for War depth, he is a fantastic 3rd or 4th string healer. He doesn't strictly
LB2 to function on offense if you protect him, but don't put him on Defense.
When Tang was in Beta, he had a unique mechanic involving mana generation stacks, which many players were excited about.
"I was waiting & waiting for this one and now he is a completely different card. Maybe I won’t even try for him now."
Many considered him a "Hathor-lite" upon release. "He is just a different kind of Hathor... still usable of course but less original."

Despite the disappointment, players realized his speed was undeniable. "He is still a VERY FAST over healer that cleanses... If that’s broken, I’d hate to imagine the hero that person considered overpowered."

Tang Sanzang is the classic case of "boring but effective." He doesn't have flashy animations or screen-shaking damage numbers. He just quietly, quickly, and efficiently keeps your team alive. While his stats have gathered a bit of dust, his
speed is a trait that never truly goes out of style.
Yes, if you lack a reliable Very Fast healer. Just don't expect him to tank the world anymore.
The Golden Cicada may have shed its meta-defining skin, but it still chirps fast enough to save your life.
